title: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
Hey folks,

Since I'm new to the community, noone may know me here [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

I run a VGM website for Sierra's classics, Sierra Music Central.
([url=http://smc.sq7.org]smc.sq7.org[/url] - links don't seem to work on this board for some reason.)

As well as recording the Realms of Chaos soundtrack (if you're interested, click the link at my site and send the relevant email), I've always been interested in working with Apogee music as well (although the only thing I ever did was one Monster Bash track :P ).

The reasons were that (as far as I know) Apogee composers (which consists mainly of Bobby Prince) aren't particularly passionate about the old music and aren't interested in recreating it.
I also didn't think there was much of an Apogee community.

But, seeing this forum makes me think.



Down to business- I have lots of Apogee IMF and MIDI files. If anyone is interested in converting IMF's to MIDI files, or enhancing MIDI files from Apogee General MIDI games (like Realms or Hocus, etc), please contact me (through my website mentioned earlier).

If I get interest, I will do easy things like record a Hocus soundtrack, or perhaps something more advanced like recording a proper Monster Bash enhanced CD (say, the original tracks then enhanced GM files of each).

Let me know folks.

Regards,
- Spike

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content: I loved the music from the Incredible Machine! Almost as much as the music from Hocus Pocus. That does sound very interesting... there were two [url=http://p072.ezboard.com/fpubliccommanderkeenforumtheclassics.showMessage?topicID=488.topic]Hocus Pocus remixes[/url] done already... they were very good, too. It would be awesome to see a soundtrack of Hocus Pocus!

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]I loved the music from the Incredible Machine! Almost as much as the music from Hocus Pocus. That does sound very interesting... there were two Hocus Pocus remixes done already... they were very good, too. It would be awesome to see a soundtrack of Hocus Pocus![hr][/quote]
There's many TIM games, so that's a vague kind of statement [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] My favourites are the digital audio from Toon Machine and TIM2/3 (same music).

Anyway, back to Apogee here [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img] (You're welcome to talk TIM or anything Sierra/Dynamix at my forums, though!)

Yeah, I checked out those Hocus Pocus remixes, and commented already [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] They're very good, although the quality of instruments the guy boasted didn't quite live up to my expectations (not that they're crappy by any means!).

It would also be easy to make a HP soundtrack, because it's General MIDI, not Adlib IMF files.
[I say that because I don't really want to record IMF's cart-blanche (mono Adlib sound doesn't do it for me for casual listening).
Besides, you can listen to them as IMF's on your PC anyway.]

Anyway. I will do HP sometime, for sure. Have TIM on my plate though [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]


On other games, I'm very interested for someone who can edit MIDI files to edit the converted IMF->MIDI files, such as from Monster Bash. I have a pretty good Apogee IMF and MIDI library, and the rewards are there- I'm not asking for personal gain (as in, do this for me so I have a nice library), but would use proper MIDI's to make quality CD-worthy soundtracks for these old scores, available to everyone for free, as I do with my site now. Ideally, I'd like to do Monster Bash, BioMenace, Duke 2, and more. (For purists, I'd probably include digital versions of original IMF's as well.)

I think I have Cosmo's soundtrack in GM (although I need TeckWrd converted) already, just in case anyone offered to do that. I'd love BioMenace or Monster Bash though [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Regards,
- Spike

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
Monster bash is possible to convert, but you need to build up the percussion.

The percussion can possible be anylized by a beat detector.
Or you can try to synch a beat in a sequencer.


I can give one easy example : [url=http://www.darkocean.info/cyclops.mp3]www.darkocean.info/cyclops.mp3[/url]

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
I'm new at doing this sort of thing... here are my first two songs.... how are they?

[url=http://www.filenanny.com/files/44f7b9c9f14e0/Bubbles.mp3]Bubbles[/url]
[url=http://www.filenanny.com/files/44f7b9c9f14e0/Math%20Rescue%20Candy%20Land.mp3]Math Rescue[/url]

Bubbles is from Hocus Pocus and the second one is the Candy Land theme to Math Rescue. In Bubbles, I tried to fade it out by slowly removing all of the instruments until the polysynth was the only one left, then I just faded that one out. I think that the drums become too much near the end of the Math Rescue song...

Bubbles was a hard one, because there were so many notes and the reverberation on the instruments was too much at times, so some notes are missing. Tell me what you think for my first songs!

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
The latest version of AdPlug should play IMF files at different speeds depending on the file extension courtesy of a patch by yours truly - .imf is faster, .wlf is slower.

This means all you have to do is rename the file if it plays at the wrong speed instead of modifying it. The only game it doesn't work for is Duke Nukem II because they run at a different speed again, but there are tools to slow those down to .imf speeds.[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
Just to answer some of the comments, like Svezzy's (you're Aussie too aren't you? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] ) :

Basically, my goal is to have MIDI files for Apogee game scores, some of them anyway (I don't care about Mystic Towers' music for example). But I do care about (in no particular order) Monster Bash, Cosmo, Duke2, BioMenace, especially MB and BM. (Hocus Pocus and Realms of Chaos are already GM games.)


I would use them to make CD releases on my website, mix them, make them sound nice. In an ideal world, I'd work with Batteryman and make 2 CD sets, CD1 being my mixes and the second CD being him being creative, like his MP3 remixes are.
But I should ask him first [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]



The sticking point is anyone being able to extract (proper) IMF's first (which I think is resolved these days), and also getting MIDI data that's a good representation of the IMF data.


If anyone can help me out with this, I'm always eager to listen. I'd love to make a MB or BM soundtrack.


Final point- why am I so interested in this and not working with the Adlib files?
Well, while I enjoy the original scores, I think they have obvious flaws and limitations that a good MIDI rendering (and subsequent mixing) would be able to overcome. I want to 'recreate' the scores with good quality instruments and make them sound as good as I can.


Regards,
- Spike

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
well, the midis of MB are in progress.
So one day they will be avatible as MIDI GS format
Thats mean they will sound incorrect whit Normal GM ( General Midi )

The tunes will be optimized for Roland Canvas GS and it use also extra patches that is not normally used for standar midi playback.
Winamp is recomended or a player that support all GS patches . keep in mind that the Roland Canvas sound bank contains 227 instrument patches and 9 percussion patches

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
yes, power drums can maybe be fun.
The MB midis will aim at adlib like percussion.
Mostly TR-808 percussion and 808 Toms, are very simmilar to Adlib like perc.

Yesterday i discover i little mistake i did, i have by an accident programmed them for DirectMusic GM/GS.

The instrument sound nice , but when i use GS only, the instruments are too loud or too rough, so i guess, i have to relese in different versions then.
Bouth DirectX MIDI and Standar GS.
the samples are the same, its all coming from the GM.DLS file, but different realtime-render technics.

Thats also explain whay Malvineous get an another experience, when he plays my midis. beacuse Linux dosnt have DirectX./DirectMusic

So, this is it atm, i first program them in DirectMusic GS, that sounds most detalied, and then i will tweak them for other playback system, [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Out of Curiosity
content: I've been curious about this for a while now...  When synthesizing AdLib music for MIDI playback, do most people prefer to retain the original, rather warm/un-precise sound, of the original piece, or to have the instruments interpreted, and converted to what they possibly were trying to represent in the original?

title: Re: Out of Curiosity
content: MIDI bank 127 on my computer has the same order of instruments as the IBK files used in the music for Math Rescue and Word Rescue.

title: Re: Out of Curiosity
content:
Well I'm certain the Word and Math Rescue songs were originally MIDIs, so that would make sense. Does the conversion using bank 127 sound any different to the MIDIs I did?

And if by "synthesizing" you mean "converting" then Batteryman is the only person I know of who likes the MIDIs to sound like the original Adlib songs - everyone else seems to prefer interpretting the instruments, to come up with a version of the song that could have been used had the game supported MIDIs to begin with.[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

content:

title: Re: Anyone interested in working with Apogee music?
content:
Here's a Bobby Prince song that is less known than his others. It's a song from Word Rescue Plus, the sequel to the Word Rescue Trilogy. It wasn't published by Apogee, but it's basically the same as the trilogy, just with different music made by Bobby Prince.

[url=http://www.filenanny.com/files/46b88e00dcbc35146/Word_Rescue_Plus.mp3]Word Rescue Plus[/url]

...no chorused effect this time [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I wanted to use the original instruments, but they didn't sound right, so I decided to put in new instruments that sounded right.

title: First Relese of Monster Bash Midi
content:
This is my first full relese of the complete Monster Bash tunes in GS midi

[url=http://www.darkocean.info//Apogee/Mid/Monster_Bash_GSmidi.rar]www.darkocean.info//Apoge...GSmidi.rar[/url]


In order to play this correct you need to set the player to GS mode.

In winamp, make sure you have selected Direct music for midi playback.
The Midi extension should be "GS (Roland) "
And Playback methode in "Misc" setting, use Realtime

otherwise it will not play the correct instruments

Players like XMplay should use a soundfont that is the same as the sounbank in Windows xp

For Linux users, a soundfont that is 100% compatible
[url=http://www.darkocean.info/GS%20sound%20set%20(16%20bit).rar]www.darkocean.info/GS%20s...20bit).rar[/url]

title: great
content: This is great stuff, Thanks for the Monster Bash release

title: Re: great
content:
thanks, as you know, thise midis are maked in DirectMusic mode.
So winamp is high recomended whit GS realtime mode.

Windows media player is not recomended

Also i will thanks alots Malvineous for assisting me and for his great tool dro2mid

I will thanks Image Line for the awesome FL studio i buyed from them and use,

I will thanks Spikey698 for guideing me what Roland midi stuff i should use. and some more.

And at least my self, for the massive amounth of patience of spending so much work on it
